Former Students to Mark His

MY ATTENTION was called
Hopkins Faculty

some weeks ago to the resolution of
the Board- of Trustees authorizing
the collection by the Treasurer's
Office of the so-called non-athletic
Activity Fee; and I was surprised
to notice two facts. One was that
the fees so collected are to be spent
under the immediate direction of
the Board of Collegiate Studies;
the other was that the distribution
of the money is not limited in any
way to "organized" activities. Inasmuch as the Board of Collegiate
Studies has delegated to its Committee on Student Affairs all nonscholastic matters, I asked the members of the committee to meet with
me so as to discuss the situation.
Immediately after this I requested
the members of the Student Activities Council to meet in my office so
that I might let them know the
facts. I also stated at this meeting
my personal feeling in regard to the
activities, and received from the
members of the council much valuable information. I was greatly
pleased by their attitude and their
evident desire to cooperate for the
best interests of the College. After
this meeting I drew up a memorandum containing my suggestions to
the Faculty Committee on Student
Affairs, with the request that they
discuss them and that, after adopting their own regulations, they
would submit them to me so that I
might put them into action. This
memorandum I gave Dean Berry
and I believe he has transmitted it
to Dr. Hubbard, the chairman of
the Faculty Committee.

of the year, with its examinations, is
fast creeping upon us and it might be
well to bring this thought of the
existence of an Honor System at Hopkins, once again to the minds of all
its students, not as a threat but merely

All the students and graduates of
the University prize highly this system and we feel that it is the best and
only system for such a University.
However, let it be remembered that
the success of such a system depends
upon the attitude assumed by the members over whom it has jurisdiction and
unless everyone cooperates and does
his part, the system will not be successful and in time will fail and another
will have to be substituted for it.

We wish to take this opportunity to
congratulate the Hopkins lacrosse team
on its thrilling victory over the strong
Army twelve last Saturday. Those who
saw the game were of the unanimous
opinion that it was a wonderful
struggle and the general opinion
among the Army followers was that it
was the greatest lacrosse game that was
ever played on the plains at the Point.
Maryland is the remaining opponent on the Jay schedule and it is to
be hoped that the Jays will take the
Terrapins into camp, and thus complete the season undefeated.

THE AIM of any Honor System
is honesty in scholastic work as well
as othii college activities through
the co-operation of faculty and students. Its success depends almost
entirely upon the support of the
students. There is one phase of the
system, however, which may be incompatible with a student's conception of honor. The particular phase
we have in mind is the assumption
that a student will report a man he
sees cheating. Here some men rebel. If this is an insurmountable
difficulty the observer should at
least make the violator destroy his
dishonest work. We, as the Honor
System Committee, require the support of the students in reporting
cheaters and their accomplices so
that any spreading of the dishonesty
disease may be checked.

Installation of the Chapter Will think nothing of advertising for
male escorts upon occasion.
Take Place May 22; Dean
Doyle To Officiate
Officers of the Hopkins Chapter
of the Pi Delta Epsilon, have been
elected by the charter members of
the fraternity. They will serve, it
is said, for the remainder of the
present college year.
Gus Burk was elected honorary
president, Daniel Miller, vice-president; Isadore Gutman, treasurer,
and Wilson Rutherford, secretary.
The other charter members, who
were also present at this first election, include George Dowell, Harold Bloom and Z. Townsend Parks.

To Install Chapter

Installation of the chapter will
take place Friday night, May 22, at
which Dean Henry Grattan Doyle,
of George Washington University,
grand national secretary of the fraternity, will officiate.
Dean Berry will be made an honorary member.
Is Famed Fraternity

Pi Delta Epsilon is one of the
foremost journalistic fraternities in
the country. It's announced purposes are to recognize and reward
journalistic ability and to promote
general interest in campus publications.
Eligibility rules, regulations, and
the naming of the Hopkins chapter
will be considered at future meetings of the fraternity.
4 Books Published
Four new books have just been
published by the Johns Hopkins
University Press, three of them in

Portrait To Be Presented

The portrait of Dr. Charles K.
Swartz, who is to retire at the culmination of the current academic
year, from active duties as collegiate
professor of geology here, is to be
presented to the University, at the
graduation exercises by his former
students and friends. Thomas C.
Corner, well-known Baltimore artist, painted the portrait.
For 27 years Dr. Swartz has
been engaged in geologic instruction
at the Hopkins. It is said that no
member of the faculty has been held
in greater esteem and affection by
his students than he.
A. K. Barton Cup To Be Given

The Alexander K. Barton Cup is
to be awarded at the graduation exercises also, it was announced yesterday by John Heinzerling. president of the Senior Class. The trophy is awarded annually to the
senior who has "most faithfully
served the interests and ideals of
character and influence throughout
his collegiate course, has best exemplified the qualities which earned
and held for Alexander K. Barton,
of the class of 1914 of the Johns
Hopkins University, the respect
and affection of his fellows, both
during his course in college and in
his life outside".

Whitehead, dean of the School of
Engineering, is to choose the recipient for the award.

Mitchell Will Lead
Group On Russ Tour
(Continued from Page 1, Col. 3)

operative apartment houses, a people's court, and other Soviet institutions of interest which are connected with the Five-Year Plan.
The new Lenin Mausoleum is also
to be viewed by the party.
Following a four days' sojourn
in Moscow, the group will leave for
Ivanovo-Voznesensk on August 10.
Only one day will be spent in visiting th enew large factories at this
great textile center.
To View Auto Factory

Returning to Moscow, August
12, Dr. Mitchell and his party will
leave for Nizhni-Novgorod, where
they will arrive on the morning of
August 14. Here a visit will be
made to Autostroi, the new automobile factory. The same day they
will leave on the Volga boat for
Stalingrad. Four days will be spent
on the Volga River trip, it was
learned.
At Stalingrad the new tractor
plant and workers' community is to
be inspected. Leaving Stalingrad,
the party will visit the large State
Grain Farms and agricultural collectives in the vicinity. At RostovOn-Don the agricultural machinery
and implement factory is to be
viewed.

25 Years' Service On The
MY ATTENTION was called
Hopkins Faculty

some weeks ago to the resolution of
the Board- of Trustees authorizing
the collection by the Treasurer's
Office of the so-called non-athletic
Activity Fee; and I was surprised
to notice two facts. One was that
the fees so collected are to be spent
under the immediate direction of
the Board of Collegiate Studies;
the other was that the distribution
of the money is not limited in any
way to "organized" activities. Inasmuch as the Board of Collegiate
Studies has delegated to its Committee on Student Affairs all nonscholastic matters, I asked the members of the committee to meet with
me so as to discuss the situation.
Immediately after this I requested
the members of the Student Activities Council to meet in my office so
that I might let them know the
facts. I also stated at this meeting
my personal feeling in regard to the
activities, and received from the
members of the council much valuable information. I was greatly
pleased by their attitude and their
evident desire to cooperate for the
best interests of the College. After
this meeting I drew up a memorandum containing my suggestions to
the Faculty Committee on Student
Affairs, with the request that they
discuss them and that, after adopting their own regulations, they
would submit them to me so that I
might put them into action. This
memorandum I gave Dean Berry
and I believe he has transmitted it
to Dr. Hubbard, the chairman of
the Faculty Committee.

We wish to take this opportunity to
congratulate the Hopkins lacrosse team
on its thrilling victory over the strong
Army twelve last Saturday. Those who
saw the game were of the unanimous
opinion that it was a wonderful
struggle and the general opinion
among the Army followers was that it
was the greatest lacrosse game that was
ever played on the plains at the Point.
Maryland is the remaining opponent on the Jay schedule and it is to
be hoped that the Jays will take the
Terrapins into camp, and thus complete the season undefeated.

THE AIM of any Honor System
is honesty in scholastic work as well
as othii college activities through
the co-operation of faculty and students. Its success depends almost
entirely upon the support of the
students. There is one phase of the
system, however, which may be incompatible with a student's conception of honor. The particular phase
we have in mind is the assumption
that a student will report a man he
sees cheating. Here some men rebel. If this is an insurmountable
difficulty the observer should at
least make the violator destroy his
dishonest work. We, as the Honor
System Committee, require the support of the students in reporting
cheaters and their accomplices so
that any spreading of the dishonesty
disease may be checked.

Take Place May 22; Dean
Doyle To Officiate
Officers of the Hopkins Chapter
of the Pi Delta Epsilon, have been
elected by the charter members of
the fraternity. They will serve, it
is said, for the remainder of the
present college year.
Gus Burk was elected honorary
president, Daniel Miller, vice-president; Isadore Gutman, treasurer,
and Wilson Rutherford, secretary.
The other charter members, who
were also present at this first election, include George Dowell, Harold Bloom and Z. Townsend Parks.

To Install Chapter

Installation of the chapter will
take place Friday night, May 22, at
which Dean Henry Grattan Doyle,
of George Washington University,
grand national secretary of the fraternity, will officiate.
Dean Berry will be made an honorary member.
Is Famed Fraternity

Pi Delta Epsilon is one of the
foremost journalistic fraternities in
the country. It's announced purposes are to recognize and reward
journalistic ability and to promote
general interest in campus publications.
Eligibility rules, regulations, and
the naming of the Hopkins chapter
will be considered at future meetings of the fraternity.
4 Books Published
Four new books have just been
published by the Johns Hopkins
University Press, three of them in
the Historical and Political Science
series. The other one gives an
ethnological account of the Alaskan
Eskimos.

brought into action each time a call is made

electrical mechanism, it records or "remembers" the dialed number and routes the call
to the proper line.

S. Ames, president of the Johns

the commencement exercises which
are to be held June 9 at the Lyric

selected for the occasion.

Portrait To Be Presented

The portrait of Dr. Charles K.
Swartz, who is to retire at the culmination of the current academic
year, from active duties as collegiate
professor of geology here, is to be
presented to the University, at the
graduation exercises by his former
students and friends. Thomas C.
Corner, well-known Baltimore artist, painted the portrait.
For 27 years Dr. Swartz has
been engaged in geologic instruction
at the Hopkins. It is said that no
member of the faculty has been held
in greater esteem and affection by
his students than he.
A. K. Barton Cup To Be Given

The Alexander K. Barton Cup is
to be awarded at the graduation exercises also, it was announced yesterday by John Heinzerling. president of the Senior Class. The trophy is awarded annually to the
senior who has "most faithfully
served the interests and ideals of
character and influence throughout
his collegiate course, has best exemplified the qualities which earned
and held for Alexander K. Barton,
of the class of 1914 of the Johns
Hopkins University, the respect
and affection of his fellows, both
during his course in college and in
his life outside".
A committee composed of Dr. J.
C. Hubbard, chairman of the committee on student affairs; Dr. Ray
Van Orman, director of athletics;
Dr. E. W. Berry, dean of the College of Arts and Sciences; and Dr.
Whitehead, dean of the School of
Engineering, is to choose the recipient for the award.

The new Lenin Mausoleum is also

Following a four days' sojourn
in Moscow, the group will leave for

To View Auto Factory

Returning to Moscow, August
12, Dr. Mitchell and his party will
leave for Nizhni-Novgorod, where
they will arrive on the morning of
August 14. Here a visit will be
made to Autostroi, the new automobile factory. The same day they
will leave on the Volga boat for
Stalingrad. Four days will be spent
on the Volga River trip, it was
learned.
At Stalingrad the new tractor
plant and workers' community is to
be inspected. Leaving Stalingrad,
the party will visit the large State
Grain Farms and agricultural collectives in the vicinity. At RostovOn-Don the agricultural machinery
and implement factory is to be
viewed.
